title: Prime Minister Theresa May calls for UK general election on June 8
text:

Prime Minister Theresa May has announced plans to hold a snap general election on June 8. 
Speaking outside Downing Street on Tuesday, she said that Britain “needed certainty and a strong Government” in light of the EU referendum. 
Mrs May said she had “reluctantly” come to the decision and it was the only way to ensure the UK had political stability during the Brexit talks. 
“We need a general election and we need one now”, she said. 
“Last summer after the country voted to leave the European Union , Britain needed certainty, stability and strong leadership, and since I became Prime Minister the Government has delivered precisely that. 
“Despite predictions of immediate financial and economic danger, since the referendum we have seen consumer confidence remain high, record numbers of jobs, and economic growth that has exceeded all expectations. 
“We have also delivered on the mandate that we were handed by the referendum result.” 
Mrs May will put forward the motion for the election before the House of Commons on Wednesday. Read More 
She can only formally call an early election if two-thirds of MPs (391) vote for it. 
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has previously indicated his party would support such a move. 
The announcement comes less than a month after Downing Street denied an early election would take place before the next scheduled poll in 2020. Like us on Facebook
